pros: big brand company in your resume
cons: just quitted few days ago , totally agree with one of the bad reviews here, everything is created for you , no room for growth. to add on to the commends, "DO NOT JOIN RF AUTO " within team in RF is pure toxic , no knowledge sharing with each other , seniors not willing to teach any skills that they know . managers blames people most of the time when information and instructions are not properly disseminated and shared . when small mistake happen , scold you as if you killed somebody , if u do well , only a thank you , no visible pay increment. work credits are always taken by full time employees. "The local management is excellent at trying to trick employees into thinking they are compensated well and learning a lot. Also they are not transparent. No learning. Almost everything you do in Qualcomm Singapore is re-use from Qualcomm US. As such, there is no skill you are picking up. You will be in difficult situation with a lack of skills to move around, and suddenly in a position where there is too much to learn in too little time. There is too much work, and the compensation is does not match that. Also, doing so much work, you will never have personal time to develop skills. And you are not going to develop any skills at work either. There are tools that are used (not developed by you), tests that are run (not developed by you), and data that is collected and shared to other teams (not analyzed by you). Overall, if you are looking to learn, this is NOT the place to be. Skills are very important, so dont expect to pick any here. Last but not least, people tend not to share things with you, and that hinders progress. Not a collaborative environment, within teams. Across teams, it is collaborative, because the company cannot function otherwise."

review_title: FOR RF360 SINGAPORE! Beware: Don't trust the "Qualcomm" branding! Low loading & hiring freeze!
pros:
Very nice, friendly and supportive colleagues. This is the only support system that can help you go through each day.
Retirement place if you want to be a yes-man or if you join.
RSU (Entrance stock grant), ESPP (up to 15% of base pay).
cons:
Too many negative experiences here, hence 1-star review. 
High turnover rate in Operation (Front end).
Low loading from December 2021 (Context: Semicon is booming due to chip shortage, yet this company loading drops significantly!).
Hiring freeze since Jan 2022, OT is also highly controlled since then.
Under Qualcomm branding, but culture and system are still RF360. Systems are messy, little to none automation (OI & IT team are stuck in another dimension?).
Manual fab with manual work!
A few sites in Singapore are getting shut down.
Very minimal increment, below industry's benchmark. Only received $10 increment in 2020.
Firefighting everyday doing line sustaining with not much value-added projects.
Very slow career progression, management favours old birds who are "loyal".

review_title: Test Engineering role at Qualcomm Singapore
pros:
Stock benefits are good, but it vests over 3 years, so keep that in mind.
Qualcomm as a brand is big on your resume.
cons:
The local management is excellent at trying to trick employees into thinking they are compensated well and learning a lot. Also they are not transparent.

No learning. Almost everything you do in Qualcomm Singapore is re-use from Qualcomm US. As such, there is no skill you are picking up. You will be in difficult situation with a lack of skills to move around, and suddenly in a position where there is too much to learn in too little time.

There is too much work, and the compensation is does not match that. 

Also, doing so much work, you will never have personal time to develop skills. And you are not going to develop any skills at work either. There are tools that are used (not developed by you), tests that are run (not developed by you), and data that is collected and shared to other teams (not analyzed by you).

Overall, if you are looking to learn, this is NOT the place to be.
Skills are very important, so dont expect to pick any here.

Last but not least, people tend not to share things with you, and that hinders progress. Not a collaborative environment, within teams. Across teams, it is collaborative, because the company cannot function otherwise.

pros:
Overall compensation wise it's good. RSU grant significant enough to inflate your measly pay that if you've decide to leave the company, it'll hard to find match in a similar sector. 
Great Medical Benefits. Phone bill claim. No OT claim, but able to claim meal/Taxi.
A lot of leaves per year (>24 days), Vacation Match - you can convert your leave into pay.
cons:
Ever since Qualcomm's anti-trust lawsuit settlement with Taiwan. HQ is all in on accelerating the Taiwan's growth at the expense of Singapore workforce. Basically SG has been deprioritized, there's a doom and gloom atmosphere among SG employees and morale is low.

The company culture significantly rewards boot-lickers instead of actual expertise. A sycophant's paradise if you're looking to advance higher. It's pathetic seeing your colleagues trying so hard at bum-sucking and flatter everything their bosses say.

Don't expect work life balance. Nobody remembers or observes public holidays ever existed. Basically you're expected be available to work 7 days a week, and people bother you non-stop even you've clearly taken Annual Leave.

review_title: Stable company but bad work life balance and pretentious
pros: Qualcomm is a very stable company, so there's no fear if the company will survive. The insurance policy is great for employees with family. Corporate identity is strong and there are quarterly team building events. Performance reviews are twice  a year, but might not be getting more increment than companies with yearly reviews.
cons: Work life balance is bad, and I have feedback about this to my supervisor, only to be told that "that's the way it is". The twice-yearly performance review system is a farce, the increments are more like yearly increment being spread out twice, and the increments are never worth the hours that we put in. Increment amounts are also dubious, and can differ > 5% between employees with same work function. The general focus is not on the engineering work, but on creating "visibility" for yourself, which seems to be the top "unwritten" agenda; if you've done good work and you don't sell/promote to your supervisors, its your own fault because its not their job to know and recognize what you've done. Some managers seems to be more concerned about VIP visits and RC activities than the real engineering work. Way too many meetings.

review_title: Cautious of Bangalore Finance Team supporting San Diego
pros: Good company policies 4 Global holidays in a year is a great concept ThankQ points is good Lunch and breakfast options are good.
cons: Start by 8:30 AM Leave by 4:30 PM. Login again almost daily from 8:30 PM to 11:30 PM. Lot of micro management from Director. Unprofessional attitude. Manager follows director's lead. All work comes with a tag of "priority". Unrealistic deadlines. Sometimes asked to work over weekends. Have to work on India holidays. Overcommitment to stakeholders drains out energy. Team supports various stakeholders who has transitioned most of their manual work. Team members can be asked to get involved in any of the work. No core finance work. More of support role, data download, update systems etc. People are resigning. Not a positive environment. Analyst role is filled by Associate at a lower salary. Hikes are not good. Associates do not get RSUs after joining. Among others only few get RSUs after joining. Slow promotions.

review_title: Most covert politics you'll find anywhere
pros: Good availability of testing equipment Get updated laptops periodically
cons:
Promotions are based on politics. I've seen people get promoted even though all they do is write nicely formatted docs and update Makefiles/Bash scripts, while engineers who are experts in their domains are left behind.

Must be on friendly, almost familial, terms with management to get promotions.

No transparency on what projects are going on, status of current projects, or how projects are doing financially.

Matrixing is common and you can get ignored by both your team and the transplant team.

Bridgewater location does not get any good projects. Just the stuff San Diego does not want to work on. As a result you spend most of your time there doing no work.

Difficult to work on projects that you're interested in. I've been admonished just for asking for a little different work on the matrixed team.

review_title: Good rides if you have the jeal and Patience
pros: Good Pay Stocks Give Food Money , Bangalore has better food Some people (Decreasing) were great folks to work with
cons: Hyderbad food court is bad. Yes , company has No Mid senior position and Mostly its Manager Centric. Sometimes it will become frustrating not because of work but because of people. Some of them have No clue about Processes like AGILE, even after decades of experience Choose Bangalore rather hyderabad Very long working hours, so forget if you want to even have thoughts outside of work

pros: Industry leading compensation which might become a hurdle if you want to switch job
cons: Qualcomm got it's reputation & fame due to their innovative work in wireless communication (CDMA) and in last few years due to Snapdragon chipset for mobile. It's still doing lot of good work however speaking about Hyderabad office there is very little innovation and most of the teams are occupied building next revision of products (be it hardware or software). The number of program managers in Qualcomm could put many startups to shame in terms of headcount. Due to large number of teams & number of software/hardware variants for each product Qualcomm is heavily dependent on program managers for coordination activity. Just too many PMs. Qualcomm has very well defined framework for process, program planning/execution/delivery and it is a matter of time new person becomes familiar with it. Strangely at QC program manager role is technology agnostic and anybody can work on any domain as the focus is mainly on coordination, tools, reports rather than technology & strategy. Mobile business unit is primary and then there are smaller adjacent BUs (auto, compute, IOT) You stop learning after 2-3 years and merely continue doing same work again & again. You need to beat your own drum loudly for every small thing you do to get noticed (you are one amongst many). The whole rewarding scheme within PM org is laughable (you can get awarded for creating a report in xls or onboarding someone). Promotions are managed & not really based on performance (fixed cycle for each grade in most cases) It's all work all the time with aggressive timelines & personal life will be compromised most of the time. Everybody is quite busy so even though you work with many people you hardly make real connections HR is non-existent

(01)  Leaders need to roll up their sleeves and get their hands dirty instead of using or manipulating others to do the dirty jobs. 

(02)  Too many unreliable leaders and they all either wait too long to act during uncertain times or avoid the problems altogether.

(03)  Leaders don’t have the correct survival instincts and not using the right mindset, attitude and actions required of them to move forward into a more hands-on leadership role.
 
(04)  Leaders continue to play an outdated business games that makes their leadership principles, decisions and perspective outdated and unreliable.
 
(05)  Leaders are lost in how to confront the ever-changing industry landscape, thus fail to reinvent themselves correctly and the business, facing and leading through it.
 
(06)  Leaders are only interested in trying to accommodate multiple agendas that they lose sight of the most important ones.
 
(07)  Leaders seems to be on the assumption that everything is fine, and having their own contorted mindset on how things should be run, the direction it should go. 

(08)  Leaders work based on one own set of guidelines, rules and regulations, putting oneself satisfaction and desire to succeed ahead of the team or organization successes, each time they underachieve or fail, they will come up with excuses, justification, or rationalization to cover up their own inadequacy. 

(09)  Leaders are self-asserting, lack of respect for others (including badmouthing their peers or their supervisors), verbal abuse, bullying and coercing reportees into manipulating data and facts using their career progression as stakes. 

(10)  Leadership team lack of synergies and visions, their objectives and focus are vague, fickle, not align and de-synchronize. Roles, responsibilities and functions are obscure and ambiguous. 

(11)  Leadership team  are blindsided or going into a situation whereby the blind leading the blind. 

(12)  Cross-site business entity (MCH, WX, SG) and leadership team are playing unhealthy political game to try and put down each other to gain upper hand at the expense of regular employees. This increases the level of toxicity to an alarming level that is affecting the working level mentally and physically.

review_title: Lots of boomers who won’t retire
pros:
-Less stressful than other tech companies to work at 
-People are usually pretty nice and have been with the company for a long time 
-Pay is competitive if you negotiate during hiring
cons:
Working at Qualcomm is like working for a dinosaur. It’s an older tech company, with the talent to match. It’s very different from any other tech company in that it moves like a dinosaur. Unqualified and ineffective leadership cling to their roles and enforce unnecessary approval hierarchies because it’s clear they wouldn’t be able to get a job anywhere else at this point in their careers. Think boomers who can’t rotate a PDF, yet keep 10 people in a meeting so someone can demonstrate for them how to do it. Managers aren’t given any training, and employees are told career development is their responsibility. 

If you just want a job you don’t need to care about, this is probably fine for you. But Qualcomm is where people’s dreams of career advancement and development go to die.

job_title: Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Excellent benefits such as an extremely well matched 401k, free healthcare, dental, vision
- Decent salary with yearly review
- Good company culture, good people, very little red tape compare to other companies
cons:
- Wage increases and bonuses are based off of an opaque algorithm (based off of inputs from your yearly review). Qualcomm simply offers you an increase off of this algorithm and does not allow you to negotiate at all.
- Qualcomm also gives out large sums of RSU’s instead of cash bonuses. This is supposed to incentivize you to stay with the company and work to increase the stock price, but ultimately it’s a way for them to have you chase a golden carrot for the rest of your career. You essentially lose large amounts of money if you end up quitting, and the value of your bonus is tied to the price of the stock which is subject to fluctuations in the stock market.
- It is unlikely for you to end up in a high level position as there are too many people at the company for substantial growth
- Qualcomm uses ancient custom software, and in general has a terrible development environment that makes the job unbearable
- Because of the bad development environment, a lot of the work ends up being administrative, rather than being
- Work-life balance can be out of whack depending on customer needs

job_title: Staff Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
The software org that I was in had excellent culture and allowed for healthy work-life balance. The leaders allowed us the freedom to take care of the work as we best see fit. Other employees take time to help you. Everyone was great to work with, and I genuinely enjoyed coming to work on Monday. 

Work on cutting-edge technology reaching many millions of people.

Flexible PTO is better than many other large tech companies and allows for more flexibility and peace of mind. On-campus benefits such as gym, cafeterias and coffee shops are great. 401 (k) match, ESPP program and donation matching are good. Vesting schedule is 3 years instead of the usual 4. San Diego is a great place to be and vastly better quality of life than the Bay Area and LA.

Once pandemic remote work ends in April, they plan to allow a hybrid work approach where you only need to come in two days per week. Depending on your team, this might be even more flexible. This is a much better policy than Apple's.

The business outlook for Qualcomm is bright. They are the inventors of 5G and are expanding into strong new markets such as auto. The acquisition of Nuvia will lead to chips that beat Intel and AMD.

Work with very smart and diverse people. There is so much going on at Qualcomm that you can always find a different team doing something that interests you.

The CEO is an industry genius and gives candid Q&As during quarterly all hands. 

Dev environments are usually Unix-based.
cons:
As with any large company, culture can vary between groups and teams. You can't generalize for a company of this size. 

Being a chip company means that most teams will not formally allow fully remote work once the pandemic ends. They expect you to report to an office because your work will likely involve interfacing with hardware of some kind.

A minority of especially entitled employees suffer from "we aren't Google" syndrome and choose to complain and moan that the (already great) benefits and compensation aren't as stratospherically high as one or two other tech companies. Ironically, expect to hear these same employees also complain about "morale."

Employees outside of the San Diego HQ miss out on some of the benefits that come with being at a main campus.

The annual review process is time consuming and basically shuts down the company for one week.

pros: They value their engineers and encourage contributions to their I.P., which is how it should be. It really was a great place to work while they had a large operation running here in Raleigh. They make sure their engineers all have a quiet place to work privately if they need to work by having offices and doors for most of their engineers above a certain level, yet also provide enough meeting rooms and common areas so that there is room for team discussions. It was a fun, great place to work, and a highlight of my career while I was there. The office building where I worked has been completely dismantled and no longer bears the Qualcomm logo.
cons: The only real downside is that if top management makes a poor business decision, which is something that every business faces from time to time, everyone suffers, but the bad stuff rolls downhill and the ones making the lousy decisions stay on, but thousands of others lose their jobs, which is what happened to my job and over a thousand others. That said, the company still took very good care of all of us and made sure we found work with a generous package, however, so Qualcomm really did show that they care about their people.

job_title: IT Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
As someone in the field of IT, Qualcomm is a great place to work overall. The company is massive and there's a lot of things to do and a lot of directions you can go. There's great great opportunity to learn and the company is definitely trying to keep up with latest trends; we are frequently among the first to try out new products and one of the earlier adopters of new protocols and technologies out in the field. If you truly enjoy what you are doing and want to get ahead, Qualcomm definitely provides you with the tools to do so. 

Recent reorg in IT has made work-life balance better, and the shift to a flexible work schedule seems to be permanent, which is awesome.

Decent benefits.
cons:
Overall compensation is a bit below market rate for the region, though pay increases the past few years have been well above average, maybe a result of the company settling the lawsuit with Apple and prevailing over the FTC.

The large scale of the company and it's monolithic structure can be frustrating at times to deal with. Sometimes difficult to find out who is in charge of what. Work sometimes gets bogged down as there can be many groups that require approval to implement. Large size of teams sometimes allow situations where certain employees can get away with doing bare-minimum work while others pick up the burden. The term "rest-and-vest" is used derisively here, and many employees are just waiting to retire.

"The local management is excellent at trying to trick employees into thinking they are compensated well and learning a lot. Also they are not transparent. No learning. Almost everything you do in Qualcomm Singapore is re-use from Qualcomm US. As such, there is no skill you are picking up. You will be in difficult situation with a lack of skills to move around, and suddenly in a position where there is too much to learn in too little time. There is too much work, and the compensation is does not match that. Also, doing so much work, you will never have personal time to develop skills. And you are not going to develop any skills at work either. There are tools that are used (not developed by you), tests that are run (not developed by you), and data that is collected and shared to other teams (not analyzed by you). Overall, if you are looking to learn, this is NOT the place to be. Skills are very important, so dont expect to pick any here. Last but not least, people tend not to share things with you, and that hinders progress. Not a collaborative environment, within teams. Across teams, it is collaborative, because the company cannot function otherwise."

review_title: FOR RF360 SINGAPORE! Beware: Don't trust the "Qualcomm" branding! Low loading & hiring freeze!
pros:
Very nice, friendly and supportive colleagues. This is the only support system that can help you go through each day.
Retirement place if you want to be a yes-man or if you join.
RSU (Entrance stock grant), ESPP (up to 15% of base pay).
cons:
Too many negative experiences here, hence 1-star review. 
High turnover rate in Operation (Front end).
Low loading from December 2021 (Context: Semicon is booming due to chip shortage, yet this company loading drops significantly!).
Hiring freeze since Jan 2022, OT is also highly controlled since then.
Under Qualcomm branding, but culture and system are still RF360. Systems are messy, little to none automation (OI & IT team are stuck in another dimension?).
Manual fab with manual work!
A few sites in Singapore are getting shut down.
Very minimal increment, below industry's benchmark. Only received $10 increment in 2020.
Firefighting everyday doing line sustaining with not much value-added projects.
Very slow career progression, management favours old birds who are "loyal".

review_title: Test Engineering role at Qualcomm Singapore
pros:
Stock benefits are good, but it vests over 3 years, so keep that in mind.
Qualcomm as a brand is big on your resume.
cons:
The local management is excellent at trying to trick employees into thinking they are compensated well and learning a lot. Also they are not transparent.

No learning. Almost everything you do in Qualcomm Singapore is re-use from Qualcomm US. As such, there is no skill you are picking up. You will be in difficult situation with a lack of skills to move around, and suddenly in a position where there is too much to learn in too little time.

There is too much work, and the compensation is does not match that. 

Also, doing so much work, you will never have personal time to develop skills. And you are not going to develop any skills at work either. There are tools that are used (not developed by you), tests that are run (not developed by you), and data that is collected and shared to other teams (not analyzed by you).

Overall, if you are looking to learn, this is NOT the place to be.
Skills are very important, so dont expect to pick any here.

Last but not least, people tend not to share things with you, and that hinders progress. Not a collaborative environment, within teams. Across teams, it is collaborative, because the company cannot function otherwise.

pros:
Overall compensation wise it's good. RSU grant significant enough to inflate your measly pay that if you've decide to leave the company, it'll hard to find match in a similar sector. 
Great Medical Benefits. Phone bill claim. No OT claim, but able to claim meal/Taxi.
A lot of leaves per year (>24 days), Vacation Match - you can convert your leave into pay.
cons:
Ever since Qualcomm's anti-trust lawsuit settlement with Taiwan. HQ is all in on accelerating the Taiwan's growth at the expense of Singapore workforce. Basically SG has been deprioritized, there's a doom and gloom atmosphere among SG employees and morale is low.

The company culture significantly rewards boot-lickers instead of actual expertise. A sycophant's paradise if you're looking to advance higher. It's pathetic seeing your colleagues trying so hard at bum-sucking and flatter everything their bosses say.

Don't expect work life balance. Nobody remembers or observes public holidays ever existed. Basically you're expected be available to work 7 days a week, and people bother you non-stop even you've clearly taken Annual Leave.

review_title: Stable company but bad work life balance and pretentious
pros: Qualcomm is a very stable company, so there's no fear if the company will survive. The insurance policy is great for employees with family. Corporate identity is strong and there are quarterly team building events. Performance reviews are twice  a year, but might not be getting more increment than companies with yearly reviews.
cons: Work life balance is bad, and I have feedback about this to my supervisor, only to be told that "that's the way it is". The twice-yearly performance review system is a farce, the increments are more like yearly increment being spread out twice, and the increments are never worth the hours that we put in. Increment amounts are also dubious, and can differ > 5% between employees with same work function. The general focus is not on the engineering work, but on creating "visibility" for yourself, which seems to be the top "unwritten" agenda; if you've done good work and you don't sell/promote to your supervisors, its your own fault because its not their job to know and recognize what you've done. Some managers seems to be more concerned about VIP visits and RC activities than the real engineering work. Way too many meetings.

review_title: Cautious of Bangalore Finance Team supporting San Diego
pros: Good company policies 4 Global holidays in a year is a great concept ThankQ points is good Lunch and breakfast options are good.
cons: Start by 8:30 AM Leave by 4:30 PM. Login again almost daily from 8:30 PM to 11:30 PM. Lot of micro management from Director. Unprofessional attitude. Manager follows director's lead. All work comes with a tag of "priority". Unrealistic deadlines. Sometimes asked to work over weekends. Have to work on India holidays. Overcommitment to stakeholders drains out energy. Team supports various stakeholders who has transitioned most of their manual work. Team members can be asked to get involved in any of the work. No core finance work. More of support role, data download, update systems etc. People are resigning. Not a positive environment. Analyst role is filled by Associate at a lower salary. Hikes are not good. Associates do not get RSUs after joining. Among others only few get RSUs after joining. Slow promotions.

review_title: Most covert politics you'll find anywhere
pros: Good availability of testing equipment Get updated laptops periodically
cons:
Promotions are based on politics. I've seen people get promoted even though all they do is write nicely formatted docs and update Makefiles/Bash scripts, while engineers who are experts in their domains are left behind.

Must be on friendly, almost familial, terms with management to get promotions.

No transparency on what projects are going on, status of current projects, or how projects are doing financially.

Matrixing is common and you can get ignored by both your team and the transplant team.

Bridgewater location does not get any good projects. Just the stuff San Diego does not want to work on. As a result you spend most of your time there doing no work.

Difficult to work on projects that you're interested in. I've been admonished just for asking for a little different work on the matrixed team.

review_title: Good rides if you have the jeal and Patience
pros: Good Pay Stocks Give Food Money , Bangalore has better food Some people (Decreasing) were great folks to work with
cons: Hyderbad food court is bad. Yes , company has No Mid senior position and Mostly its Manager Centric. Sometimes it will become frustrating not because of work but because of people. Some of them have No clue about Processes like AGILE, even after decades of experience Choose Bangalore rather hyderabad Very long working hours, so forget if you want to even have thoughts outside of work

pros: Industry leading compensation which might become a hurdle if you want to switch job
cons: Qualcomm got it's reputation & fame due to their innovative work in wireless communication (CDMA) and in last few years due to Snapdragon chipset for mobile. It's still doing lot of good work however speaking about Hyderabad office there is very little innovation and most of the teams are occupied building next revision of products (be it hardware or software). The number of program managers in Qualcomm could put many startups to shame in terms of headcount. Due to large number of teams & number of software/hardware variants for each product Qualcomm is heavily dependent on program managers for coordination activity. Just too many PMs. Qualcomm has very well defined framework for process, program planning/execution/delivery and it is a matter of time new person becomes familiar with it. Strangely at QC program manager role is technology agnostic and anybody can work on any domain as the focus is mainly on coordination, tools, reports rather than technology & strategy. Mobile business unit is primary and then there are smaller adjacent BUs (auto, compute, IOT) You stop learning after 2-3 years and merely continue doing same work again & again. You need to beat your own drum loudly for every small thing you do to get noticed (you are one amongst many). The whole rewarding scheme within PM org is laughable (you can get awarded for creating a report in xls or onboarding someone). Promotions are managed & not really based on performance (fixed cycle for each grade in most cases) It's all work all the time with aggressive timelines & personal life will be compromised most of the time. Everybody is quite busy so even though you work with many people you hardly make real connections HR is non-existent

pros: A few good talented comrades who strive to be a better version of themselves but unable to spread their wings under the current tutelage due to various circumstances.
cons:
(01)  Leaders need to roll up their sleeves and get their hands dirty instead of using or manipulating others to do the dirty jobs. 

(02)  Too many unreliable leaders and they all either wait too long to act during uncertain times or avoid the problems altogether.

(03)  Leaders don’t have the correct survival instincts and not using the right mindset, attitude and actions required of them to move forward into a more hands-on leadership role.
 
(04)  Leaders continue to play an outdated business games that makes their leadership principles, decisions and perspective outdated and unreliable.
 
(05)  Leaders are lost in how to confront the ever-changing industry landscape, thus fail to reinvent themselves correctly and the business, facing and leading through it.
 
(06)  Leaders are only interested in trying to accommodate multiple agendas that they lose sight of the most important ones.
 
(07)  Leaders seems to be on the assumption that everything is fine, and having their own contorted mindset on how things should be run, the direction it should go. 

(08)  Leaders work based on one own set of guidelines, rules and regulations, putting oneself satisfaction and desire to succeed ahead of the team or organization successes, each time they underachieve or fail, they will come up with excuses, justification, or rationalization to cover up their own inadequacy. 

(09)  Leaders are self-asserting, lack of respect for others (including badmouthing their peers or their supervisors), verbal abuse, bullying and coercing reportees into manipulating data and facts using their career progression as stakes. 

(10)  Leadership team lack of synergies and visions, their objectives and focus are vague, fickle, not align and de-synchronize. Roles, responsibilities and functions are obscure and ambiguous. 

(11)  Leadership team  are blindsided or going into a situation whereby the blind leading the blind. 

(12)  Cross-site business entity (MCH, WX, SG) and leadership team are playing unhealthy political game to try and put down each other to gain upper hand at the expense of regular employees. This increases the level of toxicity to an alarming level that is affecting the working level mentally and physically.

review_title: Lots of boomers who won’t retire
pros:
-Less stressful than other tech companies to work at 
-People are usually pretty nice and have been with the company for a long time 
-Pay is competitive if you negotiate during hiring
cons:
Working at Qualcomm is like working for a dinosaur. It’s an older tech company, with the talent to match. It’s very different from any other tech company in that it moves like a dinosaur. Unqualified and ineffective leadership cling to their roles and enforce unnecessary approval hierarchies because it’s clear they wouldn’t be able to get a job anywhere else at this point in their careers. Think boomers who can’t rotate a PDF, yet keep 10 people in a meeting so someone can demonstrate for them how to do it. Managers aren’t given any training, and employees are told career development is their responsibility. 

If you just want a job you don’t need to care about, this is probably fine for you. But Qualcomm is where people’s dreams of career advancement and development go to die.

job_title: Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Excellent benefits such as an extremely well matched 401k, free healthcare, dental, vision
- Decent salary with yearly review
- Good company culture, good people, very little red tape compare to other companies
cons:
- Wage increases and bonuses are based off of an opaque algorithm (based off of inputs from your yearly review). Qualcomm simply offers you an increase off of this algorithm and does not allow you to negotiate at all.
- Qualcomm also gives out large sums of RSU’s instead of cash bonuses. This is supposed to incentivize you to stay with the company and work to increase the stock price, but ultimately it’s a way for them to have you chase a golden carrot for the rest of your career. You essentially lose large amounts of money if you end up quitting, and the value of your bonus is tied to the price of the stock which is subject to fluctuations in the stock market.
- It is unlikely for you to end up in a high level position as there are too many people at the company for substantial growth
- Qualcomm uses ancient custom software, and in general has a terrible development environment that makes the job unbearable
- Because of the bad development environment, a lot of the work ends up being administrative, rather than being
- Work-life balance can be out of whack depending on customer needs

pros:
Decent compensation, good communication, lots of smart people. I think there are pretty good opportunities to learn and move into new job opportunities, and we're creating and testing the next generation of technologies in the lab. That's pretty cool.

-They are resisting fully remote work for most employees. It'll be interesting to see how this evolves.

job_title: Staff Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
The software org that I was in had excellent culture and allowed for healthy work-life balance. The leaders allowed us the freedom to take care of the work as we best see fit. Other employees take time to help you. Everyone was great to work with, and I genuinely enjoyed coming to work on Monday. 

Work on cutting-edge technology reaching many millions of people.

Flexible PTO is better than many other large tech companies and allows for more flexibility and peace of mind. On-campus benefits such as gym, cafeterias and coffee shops are great. 401 (k) match, ESPP program and donation matching are good. Vesting schedule is 3 years instead of the usual 4. San Diego is a great place to be and vastly better quality of life than the Bay Area and LA.

Once pandemic remote work ends in April, they plan to allow a hybrid work approach where you only need to come in two days per week. Depending on your team, this might be even more flexible. This is a much better policy than Apple's.

The business outlook for Qualcomm is bright. They are the inventors of 5G and are expanding into strong new markets such as auto. The acquisition of Nuvia will lead to chips that beat Intel and AMD.

Work with very smart and diverse people. There is so much going on at Qualcomm that you can always find a different team doing something that interests you.

The CEO is an industry genius and gives candid Q&As during quarterly all hands. 

Dev environments are usually Unix-based.
cons:
As with any large company, culture can vary between groups and teams. You can't generalize for a company of this size. 

Being a chip company means that most teams will not formally allow fully remote work once the pandemic ends. They expect you to report to an office because your work will likely involve interfacing with hardware of some kind.

A minority of especially entitled employees suffer from "we aren't Google" syndrome and choose to complain and moan that the (already great) benefits and compensation aren't as stratospherically high as one or two other tech companies. Ironically, expect to hear these same employees also complain about "morale."

Employees outside of the San Diego HQ miss out on some of the benefits that come with being at a main campus.

The annual review process is time consuming and basically shuts down the company for one week.

pros: They value their engineers and encourage contributions to their I.P., which is how it should be. It really was a great place to work while they had a large operation running here in Raleigh. They make sure their engineers all have a quiet place to work privately if they need to work by having offices and doors for most of their engineers above a certain level, yet also provide enough meeting rooms and common areas so that there is room for team discussions. It was a fun, great place to work, and a highlight of my career while I was there. The office building where I worked has been completely dismantled and no longer bears the Qualcomm logo.
cons: The only real downside is that if top management makes a poor business decision, which is something that every business faces from time to time, everyone suffers, but the bad stuff rolls downhill and the ones making the lousy decisions stay on, but thousands of others lose their jobs, which is what happened to my job and over a thousand others. That said, the company still took very good care of all of us and made sure we found work with a generous package, however, so Qualcomm really did show that they care about their people.

job_title: IT Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
As someone in the field of IT, Qualcomm is a great place to work overall. The company is massive and there's a lot of things to do and a lot of directions you can go. There's great great opportunity to learn and the company is definitely trying to keep up with latest trends; we are frequently among the first to try out new products and one of the earlier adopters of new protocols and technologies out in the field. If you truly enjoy what you are doing and want to get ahead, Qualcomm definitely provides you with the tools to do so. 

Recent reorg in IT has made work-life balance better, and the shift to a flexible work schedule seems to be permanent, which is awesome.

Decent benefits.
cons:
Overall compensation is a bit below market rate for the region, though pay increases the past few years have been well above average, maybe a result of the company settling the lawsuit with Apple and prevailing over the FTC.

The large scale of the company and it's monolithic structure can be frustrating at times to deal with. Sometimes difficult to find out who is in charge of what. Work sometimes gets bogged down as there can be many groups that require approval to implement. Large size of teams sometimes allow situations where certain employees can get away with doing bare-minimum work while others pick up the burden. The term "rest-and-vest" is used derisively here, and many employees are just waiting to retire.
